TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi serializable beforefieldinit IPAddress extends System.Object

Docs.summary: Provides an Internet Protocol (IP) address.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress> class contains the address of a computer on an IP network.
## Examples The following code example shows how to query a server to obtain the family addresses and the IP addresses it supports.
[!code-cpp[System.Net.IPAddress#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress/CPP/ipaddress.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Net.IPAddress#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress/CS/ipaddress.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Net.IPAddress#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress/VB/ipaddress.vb#1)]

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(unsigned int8[] address) cil managed

Docs.param: The byte array value of the IP address.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the address specified as a array.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress> is created with the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Address%2A> property set to `address`.
If the length of `address` is 4, <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.%23ctor%28System.Byte%5B%5D%29> constructs an IPv4 address; otherwise, an IPv6 address with a scope of 0 is constructed.
The <xref:System.Byte> array is assumed to be in network byte order with the most significant byte first in index position 0.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(int64 newAddress) cil managed

Docs.param: The long value of the IP address. For example, the value 0x2414188f in big-endian format would be the IP address "143.24.20.36".
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the address specified as an .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress> instance is created with the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Address%2A> property set to `newAddress`.
The <xref:System.Int64> value is assumed to be in network byte order.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(valuetype System.ReadOnlySpan`1<unsigned int8> address) cil managed
Public Sub New (address As ReadOnlySpan(Of Byte))

Docs.summary: To be added.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor(unsigned int8[] address, int64 scopeid) cil managed
Public Sub New (address As Byte(), scopeid As Long)

Docs.param: The byte array value of the IP address.
The long value of the scope identifier.
Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class with the address specified as a array and the specified scope identifier.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This constructor instantiates an IPv6 address. The `scopeid` identifies a network interface in the case of a link-local address. The scope is valid only for link-local and site-local addresses.
The <xref:System.Byte> array is assumed to be in network byte order with the most significant byte first in index position 0.

Public Sub New (address As ReadOnlySpan(Of Byte), scopeid As Long)

Docs.summary: To be added.

Docs.summary: An Internet Protocol (IP) address.
Docs.value: The long value of the IP address.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This property is obsolete. Use <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.GetAddressBytes%2A>.
To convert <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Address%2A> to dotted-quad notation, use the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.ToString%2A> method.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Net.IPAddress Any
Public Shared ReadOnly Any As IPAddress

Docs.summary: Provides an IP address that indicates that the server must listen for client activity on all network interfaces. This field is read-only.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.Sockets.Socket.Bind%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method uses the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Any> field to indicate that a <xref:System.Net.Sockets.Socket> instance must listen for client activity on all network interfaces.
The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Any> field is equivalent to 0.0.0.0 in dotted-quad notation.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Net.IPAddress Broadcast
Public Shared ReadOnly Broadcast As IPAddress

Docs.summary: Provides the IP broadcast address. This field is read-only.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Broadcast> field is equivalent to 255.255.255.255 in dotted-quad notation.
## Examples The following example prints the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Broadcast> address to the console.

Docs.summary: Returns a hash value for an IP address.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.GetHashCode%2A> method returns a hash code of the IP address. This value can be used as a key in hash tables.

Docs.summary: Converts a value from host byte order to network byte order.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig int16 HostToNetworkOrder(int16 host) cil managed
Public Shared Function HostToNetworkOrder (host As Short) As Short

Docs.param: The number to convert, expressed in host byte order.
Docs.summary: Converts a short value from host byte order to network byte order.
Docs.returns: A short value, expressed in network byte order.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Different computers use different conventions for ordering the bytes within multibyte integer values. Some computers put the most significant byte first (known as big-endian order) and others put the least-significant byte first (known as little-endian order). To work with computers that use different byte ordering, all integer values that are sent over the network are sent in network byte order which has the most significant byte first.
The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.HostToNetworkOrder%2A> method converts multibyte integer values that are stored on the host system from the byte order used by the host to the byte order used by the network.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig int32 HostToNetworkOrder(int32 host) cil managed
Public Shared Function HostToNetworkOrder (host As Integer) As Integer

Docs.param: The number to convert, expressed in host byte order.
Docs.summary: Converts an integer value from host byte order to network byte order.
Docs.returns: An integer value, expressed in network byte order.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Different computers use different conventions for ordering the bytes within multibyte integer values. Some computers put the most significant byte first (known as big-endian order) and others put the least-significant byte first (known as little-endian order). To work with computers that use different byte ordering, all integer values that are sent over the network are sent in network byte order which has the most significant byte first.
The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.HostToNetworkOrder%2A> method converts multibyte integer values that are stored on the host system from the byte order used by the host to the byte order used by the network.

Public Shared Function HostToNetworkOrder (host As Long) As Long

Docs.param: The number to convert, expressed in host byte order.
Docs.summary: Converts a long value from host byte order to network byte order.
Docs.returns: A long value, expressed in network byte order.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Different computers use different conventions for ordering the bytes within multibyte integer values. Some computers put the most significant byte first (known as big-endian order) and others put the least-significant byte first (known as little-endian order). To work with computers that use different byte ordering, all integer values that are sent over the network are sent in network byte order which has the most significant byte first.
The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.HostToNetworkOrder%2A> method converts multibyte integer values that are stored on the host system from the byte order used by the host to the byte order used by the network.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Net.IPAddress IPv6Any
Public Shared ReadOnly IPv6Any As IPAddress

Docs.summary: The method uses the field to indicate that a must listen for client activity on all network interfaces.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6Any> field is equivalent to 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0 in colon-hexadecimal notation, or to :: in compact notation.
## Examples The following code example displays the value of the current host's Any address in standard compressed format.
[!code-cpp[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#2](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/CPP/noneanyloopback.cpp#2)] [!code-csharp[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#2](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/CS/noneanyloopback.cs#2)] [!code-vb[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#2](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/VB/noneanyloopback.vb#2)]

Public Shared ReadOnly IPv6Loopback As IPAddress

Docs.summary: Provides the IP loopback address. This property is read-only.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6Loopback> field is equivalent to 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:1 in colon-hexadecimal notation, or to ::1 in compact notation.
## Examples The following code example displays the value of the current host's loopback address in standard compressed format.
[!code-cpp[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/CPP/noneanyloopback.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/CS/noneanyloopback.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/VB/noneanyloopback.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Net.IPAddress IPv6None
Public Shared ReadOnly IPv6None As IPAddress

Docs.summary: Provides an IP address that indicates that no network interface should be used. This property is read-only.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.Sockets.Socket.Bind%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method uses the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6None> field to indicate that a <xref:System.Net.Sockets.Socket> must not listen for client activity. The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6None> field is equivalent to 0:0:0:0:0:0:0:0 in colon-hexadecimal notation, or to ::0 in compact notation.
## Examples The following code example displays the value of the current host's None address in standard compressed format.
[!code-cpp[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#3](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/CPP/noneanyloopback.cpp#3)] [!code-csharp[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/CS/noneanyloopback.cs#3)] [!code-vb[System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IPv6NoneAnyLoopback/VB/noneanyloopback.vb#3)]

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsIPv4MappedToIPv6 As Boolean
public: property bool IsIPv4MappedToIPv6 { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets whether the IP address is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address.
Docs.value:
Returns .
if the IP address is an IPv4-mapped IPv6 address; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Dual-stack sockets always require IPv6 addresses. The ability to interact with an IPv4 address requires the use of the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format. Any IPv4 addresses must be represented in the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format which enables an IPv6 only application to communicate with an IPv4 node. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format allows the IPv4 address of an IPv4 node to be represented as an IPv6 address. The IPv4 address is encoded into the low-order 32 bits of the IPv6 address, and the high-order 96 bits hold the fixed prefix 0:0:0:0:0:FFFF. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format is specified in RFC 4291. For more information, see [www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4291.txt](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=92231).

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsIPv6LinkLocal As Boolean
public: property bool IsIPv6LinkLocal { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets whether the address is an IPv6 link local address.
Docs.value: if the IP address is an IPv6 link local address; otherwise, .

public: property bool IsIPv6Multicast { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets whether the address is an IPv6 multicast global address.
Docs.value: if the IP address is an IPv6 multicast global address; otherwise, .

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsIPv6SiteLocal As Boolean
public: property bool IsIPv6SiteLocal { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets whether the address is an IPv6 site local address.
Docs.value: if the IP address is an IPv6 site local address; otherwise, .

MemberSignature.Value: Public ReadOnly Property IsIPv6Teredo As Boolean
public: property bool IsIPv6Teredo { bool get(); };

Docs.summary: Gets whether the address is an IPv6 Teredo address.
Docs.value: if the IP address is an IPv6 Teredo address; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks A Teredo address is an IPv6 address with the prefix of 2001::/32. Teredo addresses can be returned through normal DNS name resolution or enumerated as an IPv6 address assigned to a local interface.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig bool IsLoopback(class System.Net.IPAddress address) cil managed
Public Shared Function IsLoopback (address As IPAddress) As Boolean

Docs.summary: Indicates whether the specified IP address is the loopback address.
Docs.returns: if is the loopback address; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback%2A> method compares `address` to <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Loopback> and returns `true` if the two IP addresses are the same.
In the case of IPv4, that the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback%2A> method returns `true` for any IP address of the form 127.X.Y.Z (where X, Y, and Z are in the range 0-255), not just <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Loopback> (127.0.0.1).
## Examples The following code example uses the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback%2A> method to determine whether the specified address is a loopback address.
[!code-cpp[System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback/CPP/isloopback.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback/CS/isloopback.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.IsLoopback/VB/isloopback.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance class System.Net.IPAddress MapToIPv4() cil managed

Docs.summary: Maps the object to an IPv4 address.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Dual-stack sockets always require IPv6 addresses. The ability to interact with an IPv4 address requires the use of the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format. Any IPv4 addresses must be represented in the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format which enables an IPv6 only application to communicate with an IPv4 node. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format allows the IPv4 address of an IPv4 node to be represented as an IPv6 address. The IPv4 address is encoded into the low-order 32 bits of the IPv6 address, and the high-order 96 bits hold the fixed prefix 0:0:0:0:0:FFFF. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format is specified in RFC 4291. For more information, see [www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4291.txt](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=92231).
If you want to use <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.MapToIPv4%2A> to convert an IPv4 address from IPv6 format to IPv4 format, you must first ensure that you've got an IPv4 address. Call <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IsIPv4MappedToIPv6%2A>, which will return `true` if the IP address is originally IPv4 written as IPv6, or `false` otherwise. If <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.IsIPv4MappedToIPv6%2A> returns `true`, use <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.MapToIPv4%2A> to make the conversion.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance class System.Net.IPAddress MapToIPv6() cil managed

Docs.summary: Maps the object to an IPv6 address.

remarks.format: ## Remarks Dual-stack sockets always require IPv6 addresses. The ability to interact with an IPv4 address requires the use of the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format. Any IPv4 addresses must be represented in the IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format which enables an IPv6 only application to communicate with an IPv4 node. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format allows the IPv4 address of an IPv4 node to be represented as an IPv6 address. The IPv4 address is encoded into the low-order 32 bits of the IPv6 address, and the high-order 96 bits hold the fixed prefix 0:0:0:0:0:FFFF. The IPv4-mapped IPv6 address format is specified in RFC 4291. For more information, see [www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc4291.txt](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=92231).

Public Shared Function NetworkToHostOrder (network As Short) As Short

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.param: The number to convert, expressed in network byte order.
Docs.summary: Converts a short value from network byte order to host byte order.
Docs.returns: A short value, expressed in host byte order.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Different computers use different conventions for ordering the bytes within multibyte integer values. Some computers put the most significant byte first (known as big-endian order) and others put the least-significant byte first (known as little-endian order). To work with computers that use different byte ordering, all integer values that are sent over the network are sent in network byte order which has the most significant byte first.
The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.NetworkToHostOrder%2A> method converts multibyte integer values that are stored on the host system from the byte order used by the network to the byte order used by the host.

MemberSignature.Value: .field public static initonly class System.Net.IPAddress None
Public Shared ReadOnly None As IPAddress

Docs.summary: Provides an IP address that indicates that no network interface should be used. This field is read-only.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.Sockets.Socket.Bind%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method uses the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.None> field to indicate that a <xref:System.Net.Sockets.Socket> must not listen for client activity. The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.None> field is equivalent to 255.255.255.255 in dotted-quad notation.
## Examples The following example uses the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.None> property to indicate that no network interface should be used.
[!code-cpp[IPAddress_None#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/IPAddress_None/CPP/ipaddress_none.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[IPAddress_None#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/IPAddress_None/CS/ipaddress_none.cs#1)] [!code-vb[IPAddress_None#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/IPAddress_None/VB/ipaddress_none.vb#1)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public static hidebysig class System.Net.IPAddress Parse(string ipString) cil managed
Public Shared Function Parse (ipString As String) As IPAddress

Attribute.AttributeName: System.Runtime.TargetedPatchingOptOut("Performance critical to inline this type of method across NGen image boundaries")

Docs.param: A string that contains an IP address in dotted-quad notation for IPv4 and in colon-hexadecimal notation for IPv6.
Docs.summary: Converts an IP address string to an instance.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The static <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Parse%2A> method creates an <xref:System.Net.IPAddress> instance from an IP address expressed in dotted-quad notation for IPv4 and in colon-hexadecimal notation for IPv6.
The number of parts (each part is separated by a period) in `ipString` determines how the IP address is constructed. A one part address is stored directly in the network address. A two part address, convenient for specifying a class A address, puts the leading part in the first byte and the trailing part in the right-most three bytes of the network address. A three part address, convenient for specifying a class B address, puts the first part in the first byte, the second part in the second byte, and the final part in the right-most two bytes of the network address. For example:
|Number of parts and example `ipString`|IPv4 address for IPAddress| |--------------------------------------------|--------------------------------| |1 -- "65535"|0.0.255.255| |2 -- "20.2"|20.0.0.2| |2 -- "20.65535"|20.0.255.255| |3 -- "128.1.2"|128.1.0.2|
## Examples The following code converts a string that contains an IP address, in dotted-quad notation for IPv4 or in colon-hexadecimal notation for IPv6, into an instance of the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress> class. Then it uses the overloaded <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.ToString%2A> method to display the address in standard notation.
[!code-cpp[System.Net.IPAddress.Parse#1](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.Parse/CPP/parse.cpp#1)] [!code-csharp[System.Net.IPAddress.Parse#1](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.Parse/CS/parse.cs#1)] [!code-vb[System.Net.IPAddress.Parse#1](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress.Parse/VB/parse.vb#1)]

Docs.exception: is not a valid IP address.

MemberSignature.Value: public: property long ScopeId { long get(); void set(long value); };
member this.ScopeId : int64 with get, set

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the IPv6 address scope identifier.
Docs.value: A long integer that specifies the scope of the address.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The meaning of <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.ScopeId%2A> changes depending on the context in which it is used.
- Link-local address. On a host with multiple interfaces connected to separate links, the same link-local address can be assigned to multiple interfaces. To eliminate this ambiguity, a scope identifier is used to specify the interface over which messages are exchanged.
> [!NOTE] > Link-local addresses, identified by the Format Prefix (FP) FE80, are used by nodes when communicating with neighboring nodes on the same link.
- Site-local addresses. A host can be connected to multiple sites. In this case, a scope identifier is used to indicate a specific site to communicate with.
> [!NOTE] > Site-local addresses, identified by the Format Prefix (FP) FEC0, are used by nodes when communicating on private intranets.
The notation that is used to specify the `ScopeId` with an address is `Address%ScopeId`. For example, `FE80::5EFE:192.168.41.30%2.`
## Examples [!code-cpp[System.Net.IPAddress#3](~/samples/snippets/cpp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress/CPP/ipaddress.cpp#3)] [!code-csharp[System.Net.IPAddress#3](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress/CS/ipaddress.cs#3)] [!code-vb[System.Net.IPAddress#3](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Remoting/System.Net.IPAddress/VB/ipaddress.vb#3)]

Docs.summary: Converts an Internet address to its standard notation.
Docs.returns: A string that contains the IP address in either IPv4 dotted-quad or in IPv6 colon-hexadecimal notation.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.ToString%2A> method converts the IP address that is stored in the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.Address%2A> property to either IPv4 dotted-quad or IPv6 colon-hexadecimal notation.

Docs.exception: The address family is and the address is bad.

Docs.summary: Determines whether a string is a valid IP address.
Docs.returns: if was able to be parsed as an IP address; otherwise, .

remarks.format: ## Remarks Note that this method accepts as valid an ipString value that can be parsed as an <xref:System.Int64>, and then treats that Int64 as the long value of an IP address in network byte order, similar to the way that the <xref:System.Net.IPAddress.%23ctor%2A> constructor does. This means that this method returns true if the Int64 is parsed successfully, even if it represents an address that's not a valid IP address. For example, if ipString is "1", this method returns true even though "1" (or 0.0.0.1) is not a valid IP address and you might expect this method to return false. Fixing this bug would break existing apps, so the current behavior will not be changed. Your code can avoid this behavior by ensuring that it only uses this method to parse IP addresses in dotted-decimal format.
